#T_SP=webanno.custom.Referent|entity|infstat
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=Recognize Asbestos
#Text=Before the dangers of asbestos were common knowledge , it was widely used as a building material in residential and commercial buildings .
#Text=Even though the health risks of asbestos fibers are now known , many structures built with the material still stand .
#Text=Asbestos is made of microscopic fibers that cannot be seen by the naked eye .
#Text=In order to identify it , you need to know what materials investigate , look for any manufacturer labels , and consult experts when in doubt .
#Text=Steps
#Text=Identifying Possible Asbestos Materials
#Text=Date the material .
#Text=Check the manufacturer and product name on the insulation label and do a web search to find out if it contains asbestos .
#Text=The date of the building or material can also tell you a lot about asbestos risk .
#Text=Buildings made between the 1940s and the 1980s are very likely to have used asbestos materials .
#Text=Even still , asbestos was phased out in the 1980s , so some buildings built during that time could have still used asbestos materials .
#Text=If the building was built after 1995 , it almost certainly utilized no asbestos materials .
#Text=Look at joints .
#Text=On the outside of buildings , asbestos sheets were often joined together with aluminum runners .
#Text=These runners were held on by small nails with no point at the end .
#Text=On the inside , asbestos sheets were held together with plastic or wooden runners in the same way .
#Text=This design could be a sign that the structure was built using asbestos materials .
#Text=You should also inspect any adhesives used to join two materials together , as they often contain asbestos .
#Text=Analyze surface patterns .
#Text=Asbestos materials often have a pattern on the surface that looks like small dimples or shallow craters covering the surface .
#Text=Later materials have a smoother texture .
#Text=While this is not a foolproof identification , seeing a dimpled pattern on the surface warrants taking asbestos precautions .
#Text=Inspect exterior building materials .
#Text=Asbestos was used to make several exterior materials .
#Text=Roofing and siding shingles are among the most common materials to contain asbestos , and will readily release fibers into the air if broken .
#Text=Asbestos was also put into cement used on the exterior of buildings to help insulate the .
#Text=Most older cement board products contain asbestos .
#Text=This type of material looks like a thin piece of concrete with fibers running through it and was frequently used as siding , corrugated roofing , and soffit material .
#Text=Investigate interior panels .
#Text=Floors , walls , and ceilings were often made with asbestos containing materials .
#Text=Watch for an oily appearance to floor tiles , which indicates that they are made from asbestos bound with asphalt .
#Text=Vinyl tiles and decorative wall plasters commonly contain asbestos .
#Text=Blow-in asbestos was also frequently used for ceiling tiles and in ceilings above drywall before it was known to be dangerous .
#Text=This type of asbestos looks gray or off-white with fibers in it .
#Text=Check appliances and finishing materials .
#Text=Aside from common construction materials , asbestos was used in a number of other manufactured pieces .
#Text=These materials can be found in any system in your home or building .
#Text=Some examples include :
#Text=Insulation
#Text=Duct Work
#Text=Flues
#Text=Cowls
#Text=Fireproof Materials ( doors , cabinets , etc. )
#Text=Eaves
#Text=Carpet Underlay
#Text=Caulking and sealers
#Text=Window putty
#Text=Pipes ( looks like several layers of paper wrapped around the pipe )
#Text=Assess the location .
#Text=Asbestos is a very strong , durable material .
#Text=It is not susceptible to water the way that many materials are .
#Text=For that reason , asbestos materials were often used in places like bathrooms and basements to avoid dealing with water damages .
#Text=Looking for Identification Markers
#Text=Identify the mold .
#Text=Asbestos was molded into many different shapes and sizes to fill different needs .
#Text=For example , sheets of asbestos were used to make up walls , and slats of asbestos were created to serve as roof tiles .
#Text=Each mold has a different location that may be stamped with manufacturer ’s information .
#Text=This information sometimes discloses whether or not the material contains asbestos .
#Text=Scan for letter codes .
#Text=Once you ’ve identified the mold , look for any information that the manufacturer stamped or printed .
#Text=If you find it , look for codes such as AC ( contains asbestos ) or NT ( does not contain asbestos ) .
#Text=Note that not all pieces will have this information .
#Text=Find additional codes .
#Text=Some manufacturers used different codes at different times .
#Text=If you can find any codes or markings on the material , try to look it up .
#Text=Sometimes you can find the meaning of the code and determine asbestos content .
#Text=Other times , information about the code is not made available .
#Text=Getting an Expert Analysis
#Text=Consult someone experienced in identifying asbestos .
#Text=If you are in question , assume that the material is asbestos .
#Text=If you need to be sure , bring in a consultant that is uniquely qualified to identify asbestos .
#Text=This could be an experienced contractor or someone like a building inspector .
#Text=These contacts can be found on the internet .
#Text=Collect a sample .
#Text=If you do not want to bring in a contractor , or if they are unsure as well , a lab test is the most definitive process .
#Text=Lab tests can tell you with certainty whether a material contains asbestos or not .
#Text=Chip off a small corner of the material in question and place it in a bag .
#Text=Send the sample to a verified lab .
#Text=Take your sample to a NATA certified lab .
#Text=If there is one in your area , you can drive it there .
#Text=If you have to send it off in the mail , follow any regulatory guidelines for mailing asbestos .
#Text=The lab will identify the material and report back to you .
#Text=Tips
#Text=Removal of asbestos should not be performed by unlicensed individuals ; seek help from a licensed disposal expert .
#Text=More information can be found here : How to Dispose of Asbestos .
#Text=Warnings
#Text=Make sure that you take the proper precautions and wear rubber gloves , a face mask , and clothes that cover up your entire body .
#Text=Assume any material in question contains asbestos and use appropriate precautions .
#Text=Quick Summary
